references.O87MEN01USGP: Menkens, G.E., Jr., B.J. Miller, and S.H. Anderson. 1987. White-tailed prairie dog ecology in Wyoming. Great Plains Wildlife Damage Control Workshop Proceedings. pp. 34-38.
references.A66TIL01USGP: Tileston, J.V., and R.R. Lechleitner. 1966. Some comparisons of the black-tailed and white-tailed prairie dogs in north-central Colorado. Am. Midl. Nat. 75: 292-316.
references.A67BAK01USGP: Bakko, E. B., and L. N. Brown. 1967. Breeding biology of the white-tailed prairie dog, Cynomys leucurus, in Wyoming. Journal of Mammalogy 48:100-112.
references.A79FLA01USGP: Flath, D. A. and R. K. Paulick. 1979. Mound characteristics of white-tailed prairie dog maternity burrows. Am. Midland Nat. 102(2):395-398.
references.O04KEI01USGP: Keinath, D.A. 2004. Species assessment for white-tailed prairie dog (Cynomys leucurus) in Wyoming. Prepared for the United States Department of Interior, Bureau of Land Management, Wyoming State Office.
references.N91ORA01USGP: Orabona-Cerovski, A. 1991. Habitat characteristics, population dynamics, and behavioral interactions of white-tailed prairie dogs in Shirley Basin, Wyoming. MS. University of Wyoming., Laramie, WY.
references.B94FIT01USGP: Fitzgerald, J.P., C. A. Meaney, and D. M. Armstrong. 1994. Mammals of Colorado. Denver Museum of Natural History and University Press of Colorado: Niwot, Colorado. 467 pp.

references.O71CLA01USGP: Clark, T. W., R. S. Hoffmann, and C. F. Nadler. 1971. Cynomys leucurus. Mamm. Species 7:1-4.

habitat_description: Cynomys leucurus habitat consists of arid grasslands and shrub-steppe environments, with wheatgrass, blue grama, junegrass, Indian ricegrass, needle-and-thread grass, broom snakeweed, silver sage, big sagebrush, saltbush, greasewood, rabbitbrush, and prickly pear (Tileston and Lechleitner, 1966; Flath and Paulick, 1979; Menkens et al., 1987; Orabona-Cervoski, 1991; Baker et al., 1999). Within white-tailed prairie dog colonies, shrub cover can range from 0% (Collins and Lichvar, 1986) to 29% (Orabona-Cervoski, 1991), but generally averages <10% (Tilestone and Lechleitner, 1966). Total plant cover ranges from 10 to 82%, with an average of 38%, and tends to be lowest on shrub-dominated sites (Tileston and Lechleitner, 1966; Orabona-Cervoski, 1991). Collins and Lichhvar (1986) reported a maximum vegetation height of 62 cm.
